stream_context.summary: The stream was heavily focused on implementing and debugging a large batch of new 3D models and textures provided by artist Biobak. Kaze worked on blue coin switches, cap switches, fish, Goombas, and a new boss block, frequently battling the limitations and bugs of the Fast64 toolchain.

development_findings.summary: Kaze deliberately avoids using the engine's 'switch bone' functionality for animations due to its unreliability in the toolchain, opting for a more stable, albeit less conventional, method of using separate models for each animation frame.
development_findings.quote: You're wasting minutes of my life having me implement a switch bone when they basically don't really work at all. Have you ever actually tried to do something like this with switch bones? It sucks. It doesn't work. Ever.

development_findings.summary: A new technique is being used for transparency, employing a separate, higher-resolution alpha mask texture to create smoother edges on objects like metal grates, moving beyond the 1-bit alpha limitations of the original engine.
There is a recurring technical and artistic challenge in balancing baked lighting (via vertex colors) with the game's world lighting to ensure new models look naturally integrated into the levels.
Kaze discovered that the NEMU emulator accurately replicates certain N64 hardware crashes, which he believes will save significant time in debugging hardware-specific issues.

Performance is a key consideration; Kaze prefers models to use a single texture where possible to allow for batch rendering and plans to hard-code static objects like pipes directly into level geometry.
Kaze states the remaining work includes four and a half levels, the Bowser level, two extra levels, and three overworlds.
The team is redesigning core game mechanics and their feedback, such as the cap switch animation, to feel more satisfying than the original game.
development_findings.quote: Oh, that is so much nicer. Oh, I much prefer that over the original vanilla switch behavior.

context_findings.summary: Kaze holds a strong programming philosophy that code should reflect what the processor actually does, leading him to reject concepts like private variables as a 'delusion'.
context_findings.quote: I think private variables are completely useless and should never exist. They have no right to be around... Private variables don't exist on the processor. Why is it a thing in your code?

context_findings.summary: Kaze studies popular content creators like MrBeast to understand audience engagement and apply those principles to his own work.
context_findings.quote: I actually study MrBeast's videos like a fucking nerd. I look at them and be like, Oh, why do people like this? How can I implement this?

context_findings.summary: Kaze believes the original Super Mario 64 models are 'awful' and is committed to replacing them with higher-quality versions.
context_findings.quote: Why you didn't use vanilla blue switch? Because it looks like dog shit? What? All the vanilla models are awful.

context_findings.summary: Kaze discovered that many levels have floating point exceptions when run on original N64 hardware, which will require fixing.
Kaze expresses significant frustration with the limitations and bugs of the Fast64 toolchain, often referring to its behavior as 'jank' or 'terrible'.

biobak.summary: Biobak was the primary contributor featured, providing a large number of updated models for Kaze to implement, including various switches, a fish, Goomba, fire effects, and a new boss block.
Biobak designed a new boss block ('Sludge Blarg'/'Net Peanut') with I-beams for teeth, a concept Kaze was extremely enthusiastic about.
biobak.quote: But the beams and teeth is genius. Biobak deserves a medal for that.

biobak.summary: Biobak actively participated in the stream chat, providing clarification on his models, discussing technical implementation details like texture combiners, and responding to feedback from Kaze and Lilaa.
Biobak created a new Goomba model that was well-received but could not be implemented immediately due to complex technical issues with its texture setup and color-changing variants.

key_stories.title: The Cap Switch Refactor
key_stories.summary: Frustrated with the unreliable 'switch bone' feature in the development tools, Kaze rejected the standard implementation for animating a new cap switch. He instead created multiple distinct models for each animation state, a pragmatic workaround that proved faster to implement and more stable.
key_stories.challenge: The official toolchain's method for animating switches using 'switch bones' is unreliable and frustrating to work with.
key_stories.process: After receiving a new cap switch model from Biobak, Kaze immediately dismissed using bones. He instead duplicated the model, created pressed and in-between versions, and coded a simple state machine to switch between them, bypassing the toolchain's 'jank' features.
key_stories.outcome: Kaze created a new, reliable system using three separate models for the different animation states (up, in-between, down). This was much faster to implement and resulted in a satisfying visual effect he preferred over the original.
key_stories.key_quote: You're wasting minutes of my life having me implement a switch bone when they basically don't really work at all... It sucks. It doesn't work. Ever.

key_stories.title: The Sludge Blarg's Genius Design
key_stories.summary: Biobak submitted a new boss model of a sludge monster with I-beams for teeth. Kaze's instant and enthusiastic reaction on stream showcased the team's creative dynamic and his deep appreciation for his collaborator's 'genius' ideas.
key_stories.challenge: Designing a new, creative boss character to fit the game's aesthetic.
key_stories.process: Biobak submitted a new model for a sludge monster. Upon seeing it for the first time on stream, Kaze was immediately impressed by the creative use of I-beams for teeth and its glowing eyes. He praised the design and began planning its implementation.
key_stories.outcome: The new boss design was enthusiastically approved. Kaze decided he would personally handle its 'very technical animation,' highlighting a moment of successful creative synergy within the team.
key_stories.key_quote: Oh my god. That is such a funny idea. I love it... But the beams and teeth is genius. Biobak deserves a medal for that.

key_stories.title: The Phantom Star Bug
key_stories.summary: Kaze spent several confused minutes trying to debug why a model he deleted from the code was still appearing in the game. The solution revealed a quirk in how the game handles animated states, serving as a perfect example of the strange challenges faced when working with a reverse-engineered codebase.
key_stories.challenge: While trying to replace the ground pound star effect, Kaze encountered a bizarre bug where deleting the model from the code didn't make it disappear in-game.
key_stories.process: Kaze tried to delete the display list for the old star model, but it remained visible. He expressed deep confusion, demonstrating the bug to his audience. Through trial and error, he realized the object used an animation state variable to select one of several different models.
key_stories.outcome: Kaze eventually discovered that the stars were part of a multi-state animation, and he was only deleting one of the five states. The incident highlighted the non-intuitive and challenging nature of debugging a reverse-engineered game engine.
key_stories.key_quote: How can it be that when I delete this, the thing is still there? But when I delete the geolayout, it's not there. Am I losing my mind?

open_questions.context: Kaze went on a passionate rant against the concept of private variables in programming, calling them a 'delusion' that doesn't reflect what the processor actually does.
questions: You had a very strong reaction to private variables. Can you elaborate on your programming philosophy and how it shapes your approach to coding for a 30-year-old console?
What other modern programming concepts do you feel are 'voodoo' that get in the way of practical, efficient coding?

open_questions.context: The entire stream was a battle against the Fast64 toolchain. Kaze developed workarounds for animation, rendering, and texture bugs, calling the tools 'jank' and 'insanely stupid'.
questions: Can you walk us through your love-hate relationship with the Fast64 toolchain? What makes it essential for this project, and what are its biggest day-to-day frustrations?

Your solution for the cap switch—using multiple models instead of bones—was a pragmatic workaround. How often do you have to fight the tools like this, and does it ever lead to unexpected creative solutions?

open_questions.context: The stream was a live collaboration session where Kaze implemented models from Biobak, leading to real-time discussions about lighting, textures, and technical limitations.
questions: Describe your collaborative workflow with Biobak. How does an idea go from a concept to a finished, implemented asset?
We saw a debate about baked versus world lighting. How do you two resolve creative or technical disagreements when a model doesn't work as expected in-game?

open_questions.context: Kaze was unable to implement Biobak's new Goomba model due to a cascade of technical issues involving shared textures, performance, and a color-changing feature in one level.
questions: The new Goomba seemed great, but you had to shelve it. Can you explain in more detail the technical hurdles that make updating a seemingly simple enemy so complex?
How do you balance the desire for an artistic upgrade from Biobak with the technical debt or significant rework it might create for you?

open_questions.context: Kaze casually mentioned that he studies MrBeast's videos to understand what makes them popular and how he can apply those lessons.
questions: You mentioned studying MrBeast's videos. What specific principles of pacing, editing, or engagement have you learned from him?
How do you translate lessons from a YouTube megastar into the design of a retro-style game or the presentation of your own development streams?

open_questions.context: Kaze discovered that the NEMU emulator can replicate hardware-specific crashes, a realization that he seemed very excited about.
questions: How important is it for this game to run perfectly on original N64 hardware, and what are the biggest challenges in testing for that?
You seemed to have a breakthrough when you realized NEMU could replicate N64 crashes. Can you explain why that is such a big deal for your workflow and how much time it could save you?
